title: CourseKata Chapter 2.8–2.11
text:
Session goals
By the end of today, you can:

Explain population vs. sample
Explain why random + independent sampling matters
Describe tidy data (rows/columns) and work with data frames
Recognize and handle missing data (NA) in a principled way
Create and recode variables to answer a question

title: CourseKata Chapter 2.8–2.11
text:
Big ideas

Population: the universe of cases we want to learn about

Sample: the cases we actually measure
Two key choices in any sampling plan:

Who counts as part of the population?
How do we select cases from that population?

title: CourseKata Chapter 2.8–2.11
text:
Random & independent sampling

Random: each case has an equal chance of being selected

Independent: picking one case doesn’t change the chance of picking another

Why we care:

Many statistical methods assume your sample is (approximately) random and independent.
When these assumptions fail, conclusions can be misleading.

title: CourseKata Chapter 2.8–2.11
section: Try it: sampling variation with a “fake population”
text:
Try it: sampling variation with a “fake population”








Now take a random sample of 10 and compare.

title: CourseKata Chapter 2.8–2.11
text: Visual: histogram of your sample (n = 10)

title: CourseKata Chapter 2.8–2.11
text:
Think, Pair, Share:

What do you expect if we repeat the sampling again?










What happens if we increase the sample size?









Discuss: Which sample looks “more representative” of the population? Why?

title: CourseKata Chapter 2.8–2.11
text:
The tidy-data idea
A useful default structure:

Each column is a variable

Each row is a case (observation)

Each type of case belongs in its own table

title: CourseKata Chapter 2.8–2.11
text:
Meet coursekata data frame: Fingers








Think:
- What are the cases?
- What are the variables?

title: CourseKata Chapter 2.8–2.11
text:
Selecting a few columns (CourseKata-style)








Often we only want a few rows, too:

title: CourseKata Chapter 2.8–2.11
text:
Filtering rows (subsetting cases)
Example: keep only Gender == "female".








Question: - How many females are in this sample?

title: CourseKata Chapter 2.8–2.11
section: What is missing data in R?
text:
What is missing data in R?

R uses the special value NA (“not available”) to represent missingness.


















NA is not the same as the text "NA".

title: CourseKata Chapter 2.8–2.11
text: Identify missing values

title: CourseKata Chapter 2.8–2.11
text:
Two common strategies

Drop rows with missing values (sometimes OK, sometimes not)










Filter only the rows you need (more targeted)

title: CourseKata Chapter 2.8–2.11
text:
Activity: “missingness decisions” (group work)
In groups of 3–4:

Imagine SSLast is important to your analysis.
Decide which approach you’d use:

na.omit() on the whole data frame
targeted filter() for just SSLast
something else


Be ready to justify your choice in 1–2 sentences.

title: CourseKata Chapter 2.8–2.11
text:
Creating a summary variable (logical)
CourseKata example idea: “Is ring finger longer than index finger?”

title: CourseKata Chapter 2.8–2.11
text: Creating a ratio variable

title: CourseKata Chapter 2.8–2.11
section: Creating an average across multiple variables
text: Creating an average across multiple variables

title: CourseKata Chapter 2.8–2.11
section: Recoding: turn a quantitative variable into categories
text:
Recoding: turn a quantitative variable into categories
Example: make a “HighRatio” indicator (above 1 vs not).








Now cross-tab by Gender:

title: CourseKata Chapter 2.8–2.11
text:
Wrap-up: what we just practiced

Sampling → variability shows up even when the population is “known”
Tidy data → rows = cases, columns = variables
Missing data → NA requires explicit handling
New variables → make your analysis easier (and your models possible)

title: CSUF Statistics using CourseKata
text:
Welcome! Choose a deck:

Chapter 2 (Sections 1–7)
Chapter 2 (Sections 8–11)

title: About CSUF Statistics and CourseKata
text: Here are some details!

title: CourseKata Ch. 2.1–2.7
text:
Session goals
By the end of today you can:

explain variation and why we organize data
make and interpret frequency tables (using tally())
identify cases (rows) and variables (columns)
explain variable vs value
tell categorical from quantitative variables
distinguish measurement vs sampling

title: CourseKata Ch. 2.1–2.7
text:
Variation is the point

Two bunches:

2, 2, 2, 2, 2, 2, 2, 2, 2
2, 1, 3, 3, 2, 3, 1, 2, 1

We reveal patterns by sorting and counting.
We use patterns to find  unusual things  exceptions  outliers

title: CourseKata Ch. 2.1–2.7
text: Let’s sort and tally

title: CourseKata Ch. 2.1–2.7
text:
Pair prompt

x <- c(2, 1, 3, 3, 2, 3, 1, 2, 1)
print(sort(x))

[1] 1 1 1 2 2 2 3 3 3

cat('\n')
tally(x)

X
1 2 3 
3 3 3 



What pattern is easier to see after sorting?
What does the frequency table make obvious?

title: CourseKata Ch. 2.1–2.7
section: Numbers become “data” when they represent the world library(mosaic)
text:
Numbers become “data” when they represent the world library(mosaic)
Two core processes:

Measurement: turning attributes into values




Sampling: choosing which cases to measure

title: CourseKata Ch. 2.1–2.7
text:
Think–Pair–Share (2 minutes)
Pick one:

Stress and school performance
Sleep and mood
Screen time and attention

For your choice:

What is one measurement?
What is your sample?

title: CourseKata Ch. 2.1–2.7
text:
Example dataset (MindsetMatters)

Houskeepr Information before and after informing some of them that their job counts as an active-lifestyle.
What do you see?

title: CourseKata Ch. 2.1–2.7

Cases, variables, values

Columns = variables
Each cell is a value

title: CourseKata Ch. 2.1–2.7
text:
Peek at structure (CourseKata-style: glimpse)

What types of values do you see?

title: CourseKata Ch. 2.1–2.7
text:
Variable vs value

Variable: the attribute/column (e.g., Age)
Value: one case’s measurement (e.g., Age = 41)
Variables and Values in a Dataset:

title: CourseKata Ch. 2.1–2.7
text:
Quick classification

Age
BMI
Condition
Zip code (in general)

Frequency Table for Numerical Variables

title: CourseKata Ch. 2.1–2.7
text:
Measurement choices affect meaning

Units and scales (years vs months, miles vs km)
Coding (0/1 vs labels)
Definitions (what counts as “exercise”?)

title: CourseKata Ch. 2.1–2.7
text:
Example: coding vs labeling








Question: Which one do you prefer: labels or Numerical Codes?

title: CourseKata Ch. 2.1–2.7
text:
“Design a dataset” (teams of 3–4)


Pick ONE scenario:

Sleep & performance
Caffeine & anxiety
Exercise & mood


Your team must produce:

Cases: what counts as one row?
Variables: 4–6 columns
Which are categorical vs quantitative
For Next Class: A dataset with 25-35 rows

title: CourseKata Ch. 2.1–2.7
text:
Share-out (fast)
Each team shares (60–90 sec):

cases + variables
one measurement-related concept (units? coding? definition?)
one expected insight about data that you will collect
